text.sentence: CPGX to be taken out for dollar twenty five.fifty in all cash: The price represents an eleven percent premium based on the three/sixteen/sixteen closing price, a thirty two percent premium over the last thirty days, and a twenty nine percent premium since three/nine/sixteen, which was the last trading day before the WSJ article reported the possibility of a deal between the two companies.

We estimate the equity portion of the deal is dollar ten.two billion while TransCanada will be assuming roughly dollar two.eight billion in debt for a total enterprise value of dollar thirteen billion.
Given the one hundred percent cash component, we think the likelihood and ability of someone else stepping in to top the bid is low.
Additionally, we don't foresee any FTC issues to close the deal.
In the interim, Transcanada has bridge term loan credit facilities for up to US dollar ten.three billion with a syndicate of lenders.

We think the probability of the deal closing is high and are taking our price target to dollar twenty five, which is slightly below the purchase price as we are pricing in a slight discount as we wait for further news re: more permanent funding plans, regulatory approvals, and the Columbia shareholder vote.

Our prior price target of dollar twenty one was based on a sum of the parts: one) dollar six.three billion for CPGX's value of OpCo; two) dollar one.nine billion for the one hundred one million LP units we estimated CPGX will own by two thousand seventeen at a dollar nineteen PT, and three) dollar three.one billion for the GP of CPPL less dollar two.nine billion of debt, divided by four hundred million shares.
Downgrade CPPL to Equal Weight as news was light on strategy for the MLP: We are surprised at the acquirer's decision to keep the MLP outstanding without providing some context for CPPL's outlook.
We think the lack of affirmation around CPPL's twenty percent growth will likely cause a negative reaction in the stock at the open.

While it's possible a future announcement could still come re: the two MLPs that TransCanada will now have, we think whatever action the company takes will likely be decided upon the reaction of how TCP and CPPL units trade.
As this is still a fluid situation, our initial thinking is that there will be no need for OpCo to issue new equity as TransCanada will fund its eighty four.three
percent portion of OpCo capex while the MLP will lean on its revolver in the near term for its share of the capex.
If this is to be the case, we think the MLP would probably be able to grow its distribution to dollar .seventy
three in two thousand seventeen, which would reflect ten percent year/year increases.

However, it could be possible that CPPL's cost of capital still shakes out to be better than TCP's, which may potentially incentivize TransCanada to drop a portion of the legacy assets it has earmarked for drops into CPPL rather than TCP.
Without enough clarity on the company's plans, we aren't making such assumptions in our model and are assuming CPPL's only asset is its fifteen.seven
We are revising down our price target to dollar fifteen predicated on our expectation for the two thousand seventeene distribution of dollar .eighty
Our prior price target of dollar nineteen was based on a two thousand seventeene distribution of dollar .ninety
Unchanged For a full list of our ratings, price target and earnings changes in this report, please see table on page two.

We rate CPPL with an Equal Weight rating as we think the distribution growth will be ~ten percent in the next two years.
six/unit for the two thousand seventeene distribution and a target yield of five.
percent ift the new parent reinforces the twenty percent growth rate with dropdowns.
Our downside case assumes mid single digit growth over this year and next year which would bring our two thousand seventeene distribution to dollar .eighty and a target yield of six percent .

We rate CPGX Equal Weight due to its limited upside relative to its dollar twenty five.fifty
If the deal closes with all the necessary regulatory approvals, financing, and shareholder vote, we expect the stock to go to its take out offer of dollar twenty five.fifty.
If the deal falls through, we expect the stock to trade to dollar twenty one predicated on a SOTP: one) dollar six.threebn of CPGX's value of OpCo, two) dollar one.ninebn
for the one hundred onemm LP units we estimated CPGX will own by two thousand seventeen at a dollar nineteen PT, and three) dollar three.onebn for the GP of CPPL less dollar two.nine bn of debt.

U.S. Diversified Natural Gas Columbia Pipeline Group, Inc. Valuation Methodology: Our price target of dollar twenty five is slightly below the dollar twenty five.fifty
purchase price offered by TransCanada to account for a six month discount as we wait for further news re: more permanent funding plans, regulatory approvals, and the Columbia shareholder vote.

Risk Disclosure Master limited partnerships are pass through entities structured as publicly listed partnerships.
For tax purposes, distributions to MLP unit holders may be treated as a return of principal.
Investors should consult their own tax advisors before investing in MLP units.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Investment Bank of Barclays Bank PLC is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.
Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
To view the current list of Top Picks, go to the Top Picks page on Barclays Live .
To see a list of companies that comprise a particular industry coverage universe, please go to http://publicresearch.barclays
